title: Trump operation killing Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi named after Kayla Mueller
text:
CLOSE The parents of one of Al-Baghdadi’s American prisoners are praising President Trump. Buzz60

PHOENIX, Ariz. — For nearly 20 minutes Sunday, Carl and Marsha Mueller spoke by phone with President Donald Trump about the military operation that ended with the death of the terrorist leader believed to be the captor and rapist of the Mueller's daughter, Kayla.

Trump had answered many of the questions the Muellers asked, and they were grateful for his kindness.

They were not expecting the next phone call.

It was Robert O’Brien, the White House national security adviser, who delivered a new bit of news: The military operation, the one that resulted in the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, had been named after their daughter, Kayla.

“It was so touching for us to know that,” Carl said.

Al-Baghdadi reportedly had been the captor and rapist of Kayla, a 26-year-old aid worker who was taken hostage in 2013 as she left a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Aleppo, Syria. She was held hostage for 18 months before militants announced her death in 2015.

The events of the weekend brought some comfort for two people who had found little of that in the six years since their daughter disappeared.

'She wants us to get them'

From their Prescott, Arizona, ranch house along a curvy mountain road, Carl and Marsha had watched Trump’s press conference Sunday morning, when he announced al-Baghdadi's death.

And then they had waited for the president's call.

Carl fielded phone calls from media, calling for Marsha to come from the kitchen, where she was cleaning.

It’s what she does when she’s anxious. As she wiped counters and swept, she talked to Kayla, and to God.

Through the sliding glass door in the house where Kayla grew up, Marsha can keep an eye out for the great horned owls that sometimes appear on top of a wooden power pole out back. They were Kayla’s favorite.

When she was still in high school, Kayla had claimed the owl as her “spirit animal.” Just before she graduated from Northern Arizona University in 2009, she had an owl feather tattooed on her right side.

Marsha was sure her daughter would be pleased that al-Baghdadi was dead.

“She wants us to get them,” Marsha said. “I’ve felt that with all my heart.”

At the dining table, Carl made a list of questions for the president. “If you don’t write it down, you forget in the moment,” Carl said. “It’s very intimidating.”

Still searching for answers

A candlelight memorial in honor of Kayla Mueller was held on Feb. 18, 2015, in Prescott. (Photo: Rob Schumacher/The Republic)

After ISIS announced Kayla was dead on Feb. 6, 2015, allegedly killed in a Jordanian airstrike, the militants sent the Muellers an email containing three photographs of their daughter, pale and still.

Her body was never recovered, so Carl and Marsha never got the chance to bury her.

“I don’t know yet what happened to Kayla, what truly happened to Kayla,” Marsha said. She hoped the ISIS leader’s death would bring them answers.

The president called in the late afternoon Sunday.

It started as a typical condolence call, Carl said on Monday. He and Marsha are used to that.

But it became clear as Trump spoke that he knew Kayla’s story, what she had endured, and what her parents had endured. Carl and Marsha found that comforting.

“He was very cordial, and it was almost like talking to a friend,” Carl said.

He told Trump that he and Marsha had a lot of questions, which he answered. When Carl paused, Trump asked, “Do you have any more?”

They spoke for 18 minutes and worked through 90 percent of the questions on the list Carl had made.

There was one question Trump couldn't answer. He promised Carl he would bring it up in a meeting he had scheduled Monday.

'We have the ear of the White House'

When O'Brien called, Carl and Marsha asked that he convey their gratitude to the force that conducted the mission that resulted in al-Baghdadi’s death.

“We know those men don’t do it for the thanks or the gratitude,” Carl said. “They do it for God and country. That’s what those men are all about. They know how we feel, I’m sure.”

Carl said he suspects the mission involved some of the same soldiers who were part of a an unsuccessful 2015 rescue mission that targeted four prisoners held at a makeshift ISIS prison.

By the time U.S. commandos stormed the compound in that mission, the hostages were already gone. Some relatives and people who worked on the raid blamed the Obama White House for not acting swiftly enough on giving the mission a green light.

“Now they get a victory,” Carl said Monday. “Naming it after Kayla would make that victory even sweeter.”

After the two phone conversations, the Muellers felt buoyed.

"I still say Kayla should be here, and if Obama had been as decisive as President Trump, maybe she would have been," Marsha said.

On Monday morning, just before 9 a.m., the Muellers' phone rang once more. Vice President Mike Pence was calling to express his support for the family.

“This administration is being proactive, and we are very confident we are going to be be able to get the answers we’ve been wanting for six years,” Carl said.

Most of the information the Muellers have gathered about Kayla have come from non-governmental sources and people working in the area still, all unofficial channels. Now, they feel like they are getting the help they wanted.

“We have the ear of the White House now," he said. "It’s what we needed."

description: Carl and Marsha Mueller expected a call from President Donald Trump. When it came, they heard what they had hoped, but there was more.
